items.title: 5th person hospitalized in E. coli outbreak linked to Pillsbury brand Pizza Pops
items.summary_auto:
The Public Health Agency of Canada is reporting a fifth hospitalization in an E. coli outbreak linked to recalled Pillsbury
brand Pizza Pops. The federal agency says 23 people in seven provinces got sick with the bacterial illness after eating or handling
certain flavours of the frozen snack between early October and late November.

items.title: Israel says it will respond to Hamas 'violation' of Gaza truce, Hamas denies responsibility
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Wednesday that Israel would retaliate after a military officer was wounded by a blast in  Gaza , while Hamas denied responsibility, suggesting the explosive device had been left over from the conflict.

items.title: Hospitals warned about rare infection emerging in Calgary
items.summary_auto: Health officials are warning emergency wards about the circulation of Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) among homeless adults living in Calgary.

items.title: 'It just fills my heart': Community rallies behind N.S. fish market after fire
items.summary_auto: When Tammy Victor arrived at Fisherman's Wharf in Eastern Passage, N.S., at 7:45 a.m. AT Wednesday to sell some lobster in an improvised storefront, a crowd was already waiting for her in the frigid outdoors. Victor co-owns The Lobster Dive, which burned down Monday in what is believed to be an electrical fire.

items.title: Diageo’s Crown Royal plant in Amherstburg, Ont., listed for sale as closure looms
items.summary_auto: The Diageo-owned Amherstburg, Ont., bottling facility is now up for sale as the company prepares to close the Crown Royal plant early next year.

items.title: Ontario plant that's bottled Crown Royal since 1971 listed for sale weeks before planned shutdown
items.summary_auto: The Diageo-owned Amherstburg, Ont., bottling facility is now up for sale as the company prepares to close the Crown Royal plant early next year.

items.title: Charting the delays: Current flight disruptions at Canada's major airports
items.summary_auto: CBC News has put together this live overview of the flight statuses at three major airports in order to paint a picture of how easy — or hard — air travel currently is for Canadians.

items.title: Canada is 'strongest when we're united,' PM says in holiday message
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney, in his first Christmas address, wished Canadians a joyful season with time to 'rest, reconnect and celebrate with the people that you love the most.'

items.title: Getting into the Christmas spirit around the world
items.summary_auto: The Christmas season took a variety of forms around the world this year, from dancing and camel rides in Pakistan and seven-pointed piñatas in Mexico, to Santas taking over the streets and canals of Italy.

items.title: Multiple Canadian businesses listed on U.S.-based 'gift card' site without permission
items.summary_auto: The co-owner of Over the Hill Orchards and Winery in Lumsden, Sask., says it was a 'gut punch' to learn their business was listed on Giftly — a US-based online gift website — without permission or notification. Giftly's CEO says they don't sell traditional gift cards and Canadian businesses were not intentionally listed.

items.title: Inmates file lawsuits against Correctional Service Canada after break-in, alleged assaults at Ontario prison
items.summary_auto: Ten inmates at Grand Valley Institution for Women have filed lawsuits against Correctional Service Canada related to a break-in at the Kitchener, Ont., facility in early November. The Toronto-based lawyer for the inmates told CBC News the women are feeling set back and scared after two of them were allegedly assaulted.

items.title: Can the answer to future flooding be found in resurrecting an ancient lake?
items.summary_auto: Following the recent floods in Abbotsford and on the territory of the Semá:th (Sumas) First Nation in British Columbia, some researchers are renewing their calls to bring part of the ancient Sumas Lake back to life.

items.title: Alberta chocolatier brings Canadian magic to Harry Potter baking show
items.summary_auto: An Alberta chocolatier brought a distinctly Canadian flavour to the baking show Harry Potter: Wizards of Baking, a magical experience she says taught her to think bigger. Priya Winsor of St. Albert, Alta., said the show pushed her well beyond her comfort zone, particularly when it came to constructing large-scale edible showpieces.

items.title: 'Grateful that I'm still alive’: Man’s life saved by stranger at Whistler, B.C., restaurant
items.summary_auto: Dan and Kathy Sickavish were celebrating their wedding anniversary at The Keg in Whistler, B.C. But after being married for four decades, Kathy knew right away when the meal took a turn and Dan was in trouble.

items.title: Truro to officially name park that honours African Nova Scotian women
items.summary_auto: The Town of Truro is continuing with a name contest for a park that a project partner thought had already been named.

items.title: Family celebrates Christmas meow-icle and reminds others to microchip pets
items.summary_auto: Kayla Gavin is reminding people to microchip their pets after she was reunited with her cat two months after he went missing.

items.title: Calgary emergency wards coping with 'extreme overcapacity' in flu season: AHS memo
items.summary_auto: Hospitals are tightening policies to prevent patient bottlenecks, even if beds aren't available, according to a memo obtained by CBC News.

items.title: EU, France, Germany slam U.S. visa bans as 'censorship' dispute deepens
items.summary_auto: The European Union, France and Germany condemned U.S. visa bans on European citizens combating online hate and disinformation, with Brussels saying on Wednesday it could "respond swiftly and decisively" against the "unjustified measures."

items.title: Yukoners prepare for holiday power outages as temperatures continue to dip into -40s
U.S., Ukraine reach consensus on key issues to end war, but territorial disputes remain
items.summary_auto: Ukraine's president spoke to reporters Tuesday to describe a 20-point overarching plan that negotiators from Ukraine and the U.S. hammered out in Florida in recent days, though he said that many details are still being worked out.

items.title: Regina Transition House opens Santa’s workshop for families fleeing violence
items.summary_auto: Women and children staying at Regina Transition House now have access to Santa’s workshop — a safe space where mothers can choose Christmas gifts for their children.

items.title: U.S. alcohol group takes aim at markup on local spirits in N.S.
items.summary_auto: The organization that represents some of America's largest spirits producers is calling for the NSLC to remove a policy that gives preferential markup to Nova Scotian spirit products.

items.title: Sir John A. Macdonald was erased from some public spaces. Now there's a movement to bring him back
items.summary_auto: The racial reckoning of the COVID era saw Canada grapple with its checkered past — a process that led to statues of some foundational figures being removed, in some instances by force. Five years on, there's a growing movement to restore some of what was taken down in that tumultuous period.

items.title: The Elf on the Shelf has been delightful and divisive for 20 years. Here's how we got here
items.summary_auto: Twenty years after it was introduced to the world by Carol Aebersold and her daughter Chanda Bell, the Elf on the Shelf is now a staple of modern Christmas festivities, having become a cherished tradition for kids and a creative headache for parents.

items.title: This ain't your parents' Game Boy: New gaming handhelds are powerful, pricey — and far from pocket-sized
items.summary_auto: This year marks the first time all three major gaming hardware companies — Nintendo, Sony and Microsoft — have handheld devices on the market. But they're all very different. Which one is right for you?

items.title: Everyone's obsessed with Heated Rivalry. Could it change how we see gay sex on screen?
items.summary_auto: Fans and critics say Heated Rivalry is reminiscent of titles like Queer as Folk and The L Word, which were some of the first to depict same-sex intimacy on the small screen. They hope the Canadian show might break the mould in new ways.
